title: The only way is up, up and away as Superbaby marks his first birthday
text:

A ‘Superbaby’ who underwent open heart surgery at eight hours old has heroically defeated the odds to celebrate his first birthday.

Théodore Clark Chamming’s beat the odds to survive after open heart surgery at eight hours old.

His middle name pays tribute to the superhero’s alias.

Baby Theo was diagnosed with rare defect, anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVR), where vessels linking the heart and lungs are not connected properly - at just three hours old.

The tot’s tiny heart was stopped for an hour during emergency surgery so surgeons could make repairs.

His mum Amanda, 32, said of her first-born: “They rushed him into theatre for emergency open heart surgery – we were warned he might not make it. It was a horrific time for us.

“Théodore spent two weeks in PICU and was hooked up to lots of wires so we couldn’t hold him.

"He had fluid on his lungs along with a number of other post-op complications, and at one point we were told we should prepare for the worst.”

Incredibly, the youngster, who was treated at Evelina London Children’s Hospital, suddenly began breathing on his own.

Amanda, from Hither Green, south east London, added: “Théodore really is our determined little Superbaby who has fought his way through.”

His dad Alex, 34, who has Superman t-shirts, pajamas and posters, pushed for his son to be named after Clark Kent, the hero's alias.

And Théodore has since proved he is every bit as strong as the Man of Steel - as he is now starting to walk and will celebrate his first birthday next month.

Amanda, a lawyer said: “We are travelling to Scotland and throwing a family party. It’s amazing - though I am slightly anxious about the day as it will bring everything back.”

The parents are taking on challenges to raise money for Evelina London, with hospitality boss Alex set to run the London Marathon in April.

Amanda - who ran a half marathon with Théodore’s intensive care consultant, Dr Shelley Riphagen this month - explained: “We go back to Evelina London quite often and each visit reminds us how lucky we are to have Théodore with us here today.”

Funds raised by Team Theo will be split between the Paediatric Intensive Care Unit and Cardiology Kids, which aims to raise £150,000 for the Cardiology Team as a legacy of the 150th birthday of Evelina London.

description: Théodore Clark Chamming’s beat the odds to survive after open heart surgery at eight hours old - and now his family are fundraising for the children's hospital that saved his life
